Author: [ Anonyme ? ]
Title: Relación del rigvroso martyrio, qve el Padre Fr. Ioan de Prado de la provincia de San Diego de Sevilla, predicador, y provincial, que fue de la misma provincia, que es de frailes descalços franciscos, padecio en la ciudad de Marruecos ... la qual relacion embió el Governador de Marzagan, al Excelentissimo Señor Duque de Medina Sydonia
Key Words: Juan de Prado, Blessed - Martyrdom - Maroc - XVII century - North Africa - Sacrifice for faith - Christian-Islamic struggle - Franciscan Order - Barbary
Synopsis:
The account is very short (just 4 pages) and relates the events of Friar Juan de Prado's mission to Morocco in the first months of 1631. The author refers that the Franciscan friar had asked for and obtained the necessary licences to travel to Morocco (Azamor and Marrakech) to give assistance and spiritual relief to Christian captives and to carry out a mission of evangelisation of the Moors, together with his co-friar Matías de San Francisco. But the King of Morocco, Muley Abdel Malik, who had granted safe-conduct to the two friars, had died before their arrival and his brother, who had succeeded him on the throne, did not want to recognise the safe-conduct given by his dead brother and took the friars hostage as his slaves. After keeping them in prison for a month, the king gave them the opportunity to be released, on condition that they left as soon as possible to return to Spain, without preaching the Christian religion nor proselytising. But Juan de Prado did not accept, because he had gone to Africa for that purpose and, instead, began to debate with the king of Morocco and to give his arguments attempting to convince him to convert to Christianity. He told him that man can only be saved in the law of Christ and “condemned the falsehood and deception of the Sect of Mohammed”, through which “all Moors are lost and condemned to Hell”. Then the Moroccan king, enraged, attacked him with a dagger and, in an uncontrollable hatred, struck him several times in the chest. Finally, he ordered the almost lifeless body of the friar to be burnt on a pyre, saying to all the Muslims present: “Whoever wants to go to paradise, let him throw a piece of wood on the fire!”.
The author of the report explicitly speaks of the friar as a “Holy Martyr of Christ”, because he was “condemned to death and burned for the faith” and adds that with his last strength, already engulfed in flames, he continued to preach the Catholic faith until his last breath.
Archival / catalogue reference: One copy in BNE (ref.:  AFRGFC / 186 / 10)
Notes: The author is the Portuguese Governor of Mazaghán in 1631. The report was written a few weeks after the events narrated, and was published a few months later.

Title: Monumento de los santos martyres Iusto i Pastor en la ciudad de Huesca. Con las antigüedades que se hallaron fabricando una capilla para trasladar sus santos cuerpos.
Other editions / Translations: Ed. Iuan Nogues, 1644
Key Words: Martyrdom ; Saints Justo and Pastor
Synopsis: This work is a hagiography dedicated to Saints Justus and Pastor, also known as the “Holy Children”, or the “young martyrs”. Saints Justus and Pastor died martyrs in 304 A.D., during the great persecution of Diocletian, as children under the age of ten. They were executed in Alcalá de Henares, by order of the governor Dacian, because they refused to abjure Christianity. In the place where they were martyred, years later a chapel was built to house their remains. After the Muslim invasion, the relics of the holy children were taken by Saint Urbicius to the province of Huesca and to Bordeaux (France); in 1568 part of the remains returned to Alcalá, but most of them were kept in Huesca, to which monument a large part of this work is dedicated. His feast day is celebrated on 6 August.

Synopsis: This is a hagiographic work in form of poem about the life and martyrdom of Saint Vincent of Saragossa (also known as Vincent Martyr), the Protomartyr of Spain. He was probably born in Huesca, Tarragona (Spain) during the latter part of the 3rd century; after being named by the former Bishop Valerius as deacon of the Church of Saragossa, he was commissioned to preach throughout the diocese. He was martyred under the Emperor Diocletian around the year 304. Vincent's dead body was thrown into the sea in a sack, but was later recovered by the Christians and later buried in a grave in Cape St. Vincent, in the Algarve (southern Portugal). His veneration immediately spread throughout the Church. The poem is expecially devoted to the last days of the Saint, from his conversation with the Roman Governor Daciano in Valencia, to the beatings he suffered, the emprisonment and finally his horrific execution and martyrdom for the defense of Christian faith.

Synopsis: The text belongs to the genre of the chronicle (events accounts). It reports the story of the Jesuit Baltasar de Torres, who in the early 17th century travelled to Japan, where he began to study the Japanese language. Years later, he was sent by his superiors to the Miaco region to carry out a difficult task of evangelisation: he stayed there for some years, during which he succeeded in converting some Japanese to the Catholic faith, and ministered to the needs and administered the sacraments to the new Christian worshipers. Finally, Father Balthasar suffered martyrdom, being killed on 21 June 1626, at the age of 63. At the time of his martyrdom, he had been in the Society of Jesus for 47 years, and had spent 26 years in Japan, where he acted as an Apostle, as the author says, “to the glory of our Lord, may he be praised in his Saints, for ever and ever”.

Synopsis: It is a hagiographic drama. The text is a play in three acts and in verse, whose story develops mostly in Algiers. Pedro is a pirate born in Sardinia but converted to Islam, and therefore called a “renegade”. After the death of the King of Algiers, he is eventually chosen to replace him, but finally he converts again to Christian faith, thanks to "the miracle of the Cross". Pedro then confessed his error before everyone and made a profession of faith, and when he hears that Charles V is coming to Algiers to conquer it, he decides to surrender the city to the Christian Emperor, as a Sacrifice to God. The moors of Algiers revolt against their king, who had betrayed his people, pushing him to abandon the city, but Pedro exalts the expiation value to die as a martyr and is finally murdered by moors, dying as a Martyr in the arms of his father.
Notes: The play was composed by the Spanish playwright Cristobal Monroy, pseudonym of Cristobal Morales y Guerrero.

Other editions / Translations: This is a Spanish translation of the lost original, written in Catalan language, since its author was from Valencia. The work was firstly translated into Latin, and eventually translated to Spanish by Juan de Molina (fl. 1517-1552). Escudero (n. 348) merely cites Sr. Gayangos’ note as follows (without describing the book or quoting the title): Gamaliel, Seville, 1534, 4to. Other editions are cited by Pérez Pastor (Toledo), n. 140 and in Palau’s Manual (III, p. 299) but each of them has a slightly different title to this one. Unknown to Salva.
Key Words: Jesus Christ’s Passion - Pedro Pascual (author) - Molina, Juan de (translator) - Cromberger, Juan (printer) - España - Sevilla - Cross Sacrifice - Redempion
Synopsis:
The work consists of three books: the first is dedicated to the Holy Passion of Jesus Christ, the Last Supper, Judas' betrayal, the sentence of crucifixion, and focuses particularly on the role of Master Gamaliel, who defended Jesus. The second book deals with the destruction of Jerusalem by Titus in 70 A.D., under Vespasian, a key episode in the first Jewish war (which began with the rebellion of the Jews who refused to pay tribute to Rome), but which the author attributes to the punishment inflicted by God for the death of Jesus. The third and last book deals with the life of St Lazarus, Mary Magdalene and St Martha, and the resurrection of Christ.
Overall, the work deals at length with the Passion and death of Jesus Christ, the Sacrifice of God made man and the torments he suffered on the Cross for the redemption of Humanity. It contains the following chapters:
La pasión de nuestro redentor, historiada ; La destrucción de Hierusalem, historiada ; La vida de sant Lazaro y de la gloriosa María Magdalena historiada ; El razonamiento que pasó entre nuestro salvador y su gloriosa madre el Jueves santo ; La muerte de los inocentes historiada ; Los Agnus Dei de San Juan Baptista ; Tiene añadido un sermón de sant Hieronymo sobre la triunfante y gloriosa resurrección de nuestro salvador.
Notes: This is an extremely rare book. In the first sheet (before the text) there is a note machine-written that reports the following: “Strictly prohibited by the Inquisition in all languages”. Title in red and black Gothic Letter within ornamental woodcut border; full-page woodcut of the Crucifixion on verso; numerous other woodcuts in the texts, which is in Gothic Letter. This is a Castilian (Spanish) translation, realized by Juan de Molina from the original Valencian text. Synopsis: The text is very short (4 pages): it relates the story of an English Protestant, Thomas Has, who in the early 17th century, following his marriage to a Catholic woman and thanks to the influence of her confessor, converted to Catholicism and became a fervent follower. He claimed that he had converted to Catholicism and was willing to die for the true faith: he was sentenced to death (together with a companion) in 1615. The same report also exposes the martyrdom of an English aristocratic woman of the Calvinist faith who, after converting to Catholicism, endeavoured to get three of her relatives (all women) to convert as well. The woman was denounced by the English authorities to the Archbishop of Canterbury, who had her locked up in prison. One year later, after being released from prison, she returned to preach Catholicism and was again denounced, being sentenced to perpetual imprisonment. She finally threw herself into a river, where she drowned, thus she is remembered as a martyr for the faith.

Synopsis: "Topography and General History of Algiers" is a fascinating chronicle written by the Portuguese cleric Antonio de Sosa, who describes, from the perspective of his captivity in the late 16th century, the Algerian society under the splendor of Turkish rule. It is a rare and curious work and contains important information on Christian captivity in late 16th century Algiers.  The author wanted his work to be published Anonyme, probably because of the perspective employed by the narrator to describe and judge the life, virtues and sins of the society he observes, but also of the several Christians that converted to Islam and moved Algiers, or the hundreds of Christian captives that decided to convert to Islam having lost the hope of their freedom. The book is of a great complexity but it also presents  some inconsistencies (above all in the second part). Antonio Sosa's Topography oscillates between a harsh attack against the Algerian society and praise of certain virtues of its inhabitants, between fascination for and a complete rejection toward the Other, seen as Unfaithful and Barbarian.
Notes: The author of this work is not Diego de Haedo, as it was firstly assumed, nor Cervantes (to whom it was attributed by mistake by Daniel Eisenberg), but the Portuguese friar Antonio de Sosa, as revealed by Patricia Marín Cepeda in a study published in 2010. It exists at least one copy of the same edition with typographical variants on pages A1 and A2  and a different vignette with the Royal coat of arms and two angels, instead of two eagles and cornucopias. The digital version provided (see the related link) is the scan of the original edition, which is the only one having been digitalised. The first edition was published thanks to the support of (“a costa de") Antonio Coello.

The text relates his author's life and war experiences in the second half of 16th century, including his captivity in the hands of the Turks. The author indeed suffered imprisonment and slavery for almos twenty years, during which he was sold and bought several times: he consider all his lifelong experience as a sacrifice for the defense of faith (holy war against the infildels), but also a sacrifice for the good and safety of his Nation. In both cases, the author considers his participation to the war against the Ottoma Empire as a means to expiate his sins, a sacrifice needed both to serve and defend Spanish Monarchy and to deserve his own's salvation.
